text: Time seems to have sped past me this past week. Passing by our future home yesterday, I couldn't help but notice the window obscured by numerous boxes. The prospect of receiving the keys at the closing fills me with anticipation. With some luck, everything should align perfectly for the closing scheduled to happen just over a week from now. Bethany and I found ourselves engrossed in films until past three in the morning recently. Indeed, we've been indulging in quite a few movie nights. To give you a summary, we watched "Thirteen" last night—a film I believe every parent of a teenager ought to watch, which turned out to be surprisingly good. Following that, we viewed "Gigli," and unfortunately, it lived up to its poor reputation as publicized. Yet, we couldn't resist seeing it with our own eyes.

Television during summer was traditionally a wasteland, dominated by reruns. However, I've recently found myself captivated by a couple of new series that have premiered during this time. One such show, "Blow Out," is a remarkably unique concept that surprisingly doesn't feature any openly gay individuals, despite what the title might imply. The show stars celebrity hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who's set on opening a new salon in the upscale neighborhood of Beverly Hills—a stark departure from his already successful establishment in West Hollywood. Normally, this wouldn't pique my interest, but I stumbled upon Jonathan on television, declaring his ambitious plans on Rodeo Drive with undeniable vanity and ambition, and I couldn't turn away. His commitment to creating "the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" was oddly fascinating. Not since the reality show featuring the chef Rocco have I been so drawn to a program for its enthralling, if not eccentric, personality.

It's been quite the challenging week. I'm grappling with tendonitis in my right shoulder, situated just below my shoulder blade. This really becomes problematic when I overuse my arm, especially when navigating a computer mouse — it's excruciating. Due to a recent surge of activity updating my website and attending to various online tasks, I now find my mobility severely limited. My energy to sketch or draw is practically nonexistent, a situation worsened by a lack of adequate rest, which only intensifies my discomfort. Currently, my spirits are low, but I'm optimistic about recovery. On a brighter note, my mother's recent surgery was successful to some extent. While she can now perceive blurry shapes and discern colors, her vision remains heavily impaired. We're hopeful, however, that she will eventually recover her sight fully.

Today's foray into laundry, with the kids accompanying me, turned into a more challenging task than anticipated; such everyday errands can escalate into absolute chaos. However, amidst this, it became apparent that people can exhibit profound genuine kindness, their motivations as pure as their actions, with no ulterior motives in sight. Even as I stood there, less than my best self, with my children's dribble marking my attire and my ensemble screaming "laundry day," their warmth was offered freely. I assure you, there were no hidden romantic agendas. My current state, which includes a humorous quandary regarding when I might next take a bath, surely wasn't appealing to any senses. In the midst of all this, here I am, writing this post while simultaneously soaking in No Doubt's music videos, all from the cluttered sanctuary of my own room at my desk.

At 11:14pm MST, I'm seated in my bedroom attending to the personal computer that belongs to the personnel director at work. While I don't particularly mind lending a hand, I can't help but ponder the frequency with which I'm called upon to repair computers for others as a gesture of goodwill. It's rewarding to serve and care for others in this way, nevertheless, I have to consider the boundary where this helpfulness becomes a disadvantage to me. Recently, my nights have been consumed by late stays for reading, and while I had hoped for an early night's rest today, it seemed wise to ensure this computer is returned to its rightful owner. *Laugh* It seems there's never a moment to rest for someone like me. As a result, tonight also included a session of watching Joe Schmo 2.

Previously, I had discussed an odd lunch encounter where my self-assurance wavered, but one detail was left untold. Prior to Pat's arrival at lunch, Dustin had been singing Pat's praises, emphasizing his qualities and his quest for a girlfriend. As I listened and mechanically nodded, the realization dawned on me that the conversation was centered more on matchmaking for Dustin's best friend than the typical chit-chat one might expect over pink lemonade with a new acquaintance. It led me to discreetly withdraw to the restroom, face my reflection, and quietly wonder if I was being subtly set up with Pat. Was this the unforeseen twist in my present situation?

I urge everyone to pause and consider their actions. It's my desire for every individual on this planet to reflect each morning before rising, committing to thoughtful deliberation throughout the day. Should they find themselves unwilling, I'd prefer they remain in bed, slipping into a perpetual sleep instead. My tolerance for foolishness has reached its limit. While I don't claim to be the sharpest tool in the shed, the level of intellect I expect doesn’t require genius—mere common sense. It’s only reasonable to call out such mindless folly. For the sake of brevity, I'll focus on a select few types of this senselessness today, and perhaps we can address others in the future. Are we in agreement? Good.

In the analysis provided in a recent post, two significant issues were identified regarding the current economic approach. Firstly, while President Bush is indeed attempting to revitalize the economy, his strategy may be flawed. Robert Rubin, speaking on NPR's Marketplace, suggested an alternative that could stimulate the economy without saddling the country with prolonged debt: enacting temporary tax cuts targeted at low and middle-income earners. Rubin's insight and reputation bring a sense of assurance, starkly contrasting with the search for an equally esteemed domestic official within the Bush administration. Secondly, the notion of handing over governance to the Republicans exclusively during times of conflict is challenged by the fact that they have cleverly designed the 'war on terrorism' to be a never-ending, worldwide struggle. This perpetual state of war calls into question the wisdom of such a power handover based on wartime competencies alone.

The lyrics from The Offspring suggest she's accused of aimlessly pursuing men for amusement. It's been a while since the last update because there hasn't been much new to share. However, a visit to the cove to watch the band Supernothing was enjoyable, and they performed well, as they consistently do. The evening included some downtime with a friend named Tiago. Then, on Saturday, following a day at work, the socializing continued with Joe, Rach, and later with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. The night ended fairly early, before midnight, but there was an early start the next day for a sports meet, waking up at 6:45 am. Despite arriving slightly late, the performance was solid, including a flawless floor routine and podium finishes - second in floor and vault and third in beam, scoring an all-around 29.45. This score provides assurance, as there's anticipation of improvement throughout the season.

Do you sometimes find yourself deep in contemplation about life's mysteries? Picture this: you're slumped over your desk during a particularly dull math lesson, questioning what mechanisms in your brain are at work to comprehend mathematics. It dawns on you then – your existence, your presence in this classroom, and the purpose of it all. This marvel of life strikes you as profound. But quickly, this sense of awe transforms into a realization of how absurdly trivial such distracted thoughts are during class. Have you experienced this? I personally can't stand it. You know what's equally frustrating? Block scheduling. It's beyond me who thought it would be a sound plan to make anyone endure a class that's two and a half hours long – it's nothing short of torturous.

I've reached the end of my patience with Monopoly, swearing off ever touching the game's iron token again. In a recent match, Andy narrowly outdid me in wealth, clinching the victory. This could've been due to me softening in competition as he's set to depart soon, and part of me wanted his final evening to be memorable. However, this minor storytelling pales in comparison to the massive headache plaguing me currently. Aleve has fortunately started to mitigate the pain, thankfully. What I'm really craving now is to kick back and relax. And as it so happens, your phone was instrumental in resolving that tumultuous situation during our At the Drive-In experience.

Today was quite exhausting as we journeyed back from Indiana. With limited stamina, I'll be selective in sharing my experiences – there's potential to sprawl into an extensive narrative. I must express that the camp exceeded my expectations; it was truly incredible. Lately, I can feel the significant changes in my life, a testament to God's profound impact. This transformation feels like a fresh start. Reflecting on the past days, we arrived at the Twiggs' residence on Friday night and stayed right up until our departure for camp on Monday. Our time was filled with memorable activities including attending a fair, participating in church services, watching a parade, shopping at Walmart, and enjoying movies.

Today marks the end of my summer break, and I'm not ready for it—ugh! I've even got a dentist check-up at 9 AM, which I'm dreading, but it's preferable to trying to fit it into the hectic start of my surgery rotation. The prospect of returning to school fills me with apprehension and unease; it's fair to say I'm extremely reluctant. I'm about to step into uncharted territory. Being a stickler for perfection, I take pride in mastering my pursuits. Yet, the onset of new challenges is always daunting for me. I despise feeling like I'm at the bottom of the ladder, like I'm a chess piece restricted by the rules of the game. To Cassie, I joked, "I’ll be the singular pawn striving to navigate the board as a knight," highlighting my discomfort with being out of my depth.

Arun Shourie reflects on the prescient warnings of Uttar Pradesh's Governor, T.V. Rajeswar, who as early as 1996 alerted the nation to the potential emergence of a 'third Islamic state' in the region. As the erstwhile chief of the Intelligence Bureau, Rajeswar's prognostications were chronicled in a series of articles in the Hindustan Times. Shourie posits a thought-provoking question regarding the credibility of these forecasts: Are the cautions more believable knowing they originated from someone other than himself or Mr. Advani, or should one discount them, suspecting Rajeswar's motives and questioning his continuation as Governor?

Feeling disengaged and impartial today – it's been a tiresome stretch at work with scarcely a moment to pen anything for the audience. Yet, it's refreshing to witness Akcron, formerly known as Tigger, stepping in, contributing her voice and insights. Not much else to report: yesterday featured "Shakespeare on the Green,” a delightful performance, though I had to depart prematurely, missing the conclusion – a disappointment indeed; I aspire to view an entire Shakespearean production one day. On a side note, Akcron’s commentary regarding the subpar shower situation hits the mark – it's challenging not to be amused at others' expense when they're visibly struggling, despite the discomfort it brings them.

Suddenly, over the last couple of days, an overwhelming fatigue has hit me. The kind of fatigue that penetrates to the bone. Yesterday evening, upon returning home, I succumbed to this weariness and fell asleep, only to be roused at 8:30 p.m. by my mother's call. It took me a moment, in the pitch darkness of my unlit room, to orient myself to the time and date amid the obscurity and my mother's distant voice. It's curious that I'm so thoroughly spent. The morning, though, brought nicer weather — there was a light rain as I made my way here. It differs from Calcutta, where I've heard it's been pouring for the last three days.

Last evening was particularly disheartening. I disposed of the partially completed sweater I was crafting after dedicating myself to roughly 14 inches of progress. This mishap amounted to a loss of about $10 in yarn, which is valued at $8 per skein. Complications arose as I discovered an excess of stitches near the armhole sections, coupled with the mohair yarn tangling and tedious to dismantle, commonly referred to as frogging. The continuous yarn breakage compounded the issue. Surprisingly, I managed to refrain from cursing, which isn't typical for me. Instead, I resignedly unraveled and diverted my attention to the second season of "Sex and the City," courtesy of the library's collection. Eventually, my frustration peaked and I discarded the project. However, this endeavor was not entirely fruitless as it served as an educational experience in sweater-making.

During our recent classroom discussion, we delved into this week's reading from Edward S. Casey's book, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World." The beginning chapters lay out central concepts of "implacement" and "displacement." Casey argues for a cultural shift, suggesting that instead of time-oriented lives—marked by phrases like 'running out of time,' 'saving time,' or 'just in time'—we should pivot to a place-centric perspective to foster a more solid sense of community. While I'm offering a simplified gist (hopefully my classmates or professor aren't scrutinizing this!), this work uniquely captivated me, as if it reached out and shook me awake to its ideas.

The ingredients used in freeze pops may warrant a cautionary note, as their effect might lead to unusually vivid experiences. The consumption of these vibrant treats seems to have contributed to our impromptu adventure, where laughter ensued and we found ourselves sipping beers on a fire escape amidst strong winds. Our night continued with an unexpected discovery after stumbling upon a closed bar; we found ourselves engrossed in an office-supplies catalog that had been delivered. This serendipitous moment revealed an array of incredible deals that one could hardly anticipate. Among these offers were notable bargains: purchasing 36 permanent markers would result in obtaining a stunt kite, while buying 30 lever arch files came with the bonus of a barbecue—deals I had not foreseen.

As I listen to "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero, I reflect on the events of last week in the Senate. Republican Senators, in a show of defiance, held what can only be called a 39-hour marathon of grievance. Despite the reality that I mostly avoided the spectacle, my curiosity got the better of me a couple of times. The point of this drawn-out exercise seemed to be a frustrated reaction to the Democrats' refusal to confirm four controversial judicial nominees proposed by President Bush. The Republicans seemed to be on a quest to demonstrate their dissatisfaction, all the while ignoring that the Democrats have given the green light to 168 of Bush's other court picks. But for Republicans, evidently hungry for unchecked influence, that significant number was still unsatisfactory. They appear to operate with the false belief that they possess widespread support to indulge in such dramatics.

The weekend was enjoyable, steeped in relaxation and engagement with hobbies put off for too long. I indulged in nature, delved deeply into the band Nevermore's discography, an endeavor I regret not undertaking sooner, and devoted a substantial amount of time to reading, completing three novels. Among them was Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," a compelling narrative set in a dystopian near-future United States ravaged by climate change and chaos. The book's quick wit, brisk narrative pace, and credible world-building were impressive, yet it fell short of leaving a lasting impact on me regarding its plot or characters. Both were impressively crafted and clearly portrayed, but somehow it didn't elevate to greatness in my eyes, remaining merely a solid read.

Returning from practicum, the initial week proved challenging; however, clarity began to emerge during the second. The issue of post-practicum distress, once veiled, is gaining attention. Afflicted by the experience, a conversation with the course coordinator was cathartic, enabling me to share my concerns and thus potentially spare another student from an inadequate practicum environment. Recently, on Monday, I encountered a fellow student, upset and intent on warning another about the dismal conditions at the same school. I advised restraint, suggesting we approach an administrator instead.

Life's bustling here, yet we manage to squeeze in leisure activities for stress relief, although I'm quite terrible at both 8-ball and ping pong. Rick, also known as "the Canuck," consistently outplays me. Our workspace features a ping pong table in the front lobby, where we often indulge in a friendly match. Recently, I joined an 8-ball competition at the hot spot, our recreational haven equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, jukebox, DVD rentals, pool and dart boards, and yes, the inevitable ping pong table. I was faring decently in the game right up until I made a blunder on the eight ball. Despite that, enjoyment was had, especially with the addition of two Dutch soldiers to the tournament's roster.

In the autumn of 1974, I found myself wrestling with the complex concepts of my sophomore algebra book for what seemed like the umpteenth occasion. My skills in mathematics have always been lacking — to put it mildly, a certain loathing for the subject. Math elicits fear in me; envisioning this isn't a stretch. In the midst of grappling with equations and feeling a rare moment of clarity emerging deep from my psyche, an unexpected ring at the doorbell interrupted me. Setting my book aside, I went to answer the door, only to find thin air. Annoyed but determined, I resumed my studies. Nonetheless, as an inkling of comprehension began to surface, the doorbell's chime shattered my concentration once more. An empty doorway greeted me again. A prankster's antics were the last thing I needed on top of my math-learning woes.

Over the past seven days, I've been completely drained. From Tuesday through Thursday, I completed the transition into my new, more spacious classroom that's just a stone's throw from my fellow grade-level educators. Having a space that meets my requirements is crucial as I devote long periods to setting it up for the upcoming school year. If I had been alerted about the relocation before the school year wrapped up, I would have gotten rid of the outdated books and materials taking up space. Yet, there I was, lugging everything along. The bulk of my time this week went into the process of shifting, sorting out, and extensively decluttering. A huge shout-out to my colleague Jill for her assistance throughout; while she was engaged with her teaching duties in my erstwhile classroom, she went above and beyond. Alongside her kind students, she managed to transfer practically all of my belongings!

Invariably, a fragment of you is etched into my essence. Our paths may not have entwined in matrimony or parenthood, nor have we been publicly acknowledged as a couple, yet my soul has harbored an intense adoration for you, resonating within me to this very day. Such memories are indelible—those precious shared evenings where we were caught in an intimate web of affection by the seaside under the night's cover or sealed with a kiss amid rainfall. The times when sorrow feels like shattered glass within my chest, it's the remnant of you, steeped in the immortal affection I once felt, an affection that lingers still...for eternity.

The practice of investigative journalism doesn't sit well with me. To put it another way, I have reservations regarding the potential implications of the report I'm working on. It's possible that my lack of conviction is what prevents me from fully embracing and understanding the drive and intense dedication required to probe deeply with questions. Raised in a nation that suppresses inquiry - where posing questions can lead to being shot or imprisoned under severe security laws - I'm not accustomed to the liberties of open expression and public challenge. Admittedly, I may not be the most affable individual to begin with.

Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I embarked on an excursion to Guintubdan in La Carlota. For many of us, it was a novel experience. We set off on foot, reaching the first waterfall after a half-hour hike, which left us breathless but triumphant. The waters were icy, chilling us to the bone, yet the sensation was invigorating. Our visit was brief as we pursued another cascade a further thirty-minute trek away. The effort paid off as the sight of the serene waterfalls and the majestic environment was simply stunning, inducing a profound sense of oneness with nature. Immersing in the freezing waters felt like a spiritual connection with the Earth, with the nippy breeze and waters nearly coaxing us into slumber.

I'm confident that my sisters have overindulged in alcohol due to the Pride celebrations in San Diego. They have a penchant for drinking that I never inherited from our family—the Buenviajes. On very select occasions, I might partake in a drink, though these instances are exceedingly infrequent. Meanwhile, Ed's departure is a month away, and the reality of it is beginning to dawn on everyone, including Ed. I had come to terms with it quite some time ago. My current concern is whether Ed will be present for Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring Bailey's condition closely, and there's a noticeable amount of swelling.

Last Saturday, we mistakenly thought the Fireman's Park Easter egg hunt for Connor was scheduled for 11 AM, but it had actually taken place on Friday. Fortunately, I had packed a spare bag of eggs, which allowed Connor to enjoy an improvised egg hunt in the park. The following day, Connor was overjoyed to discover the Easter Bunny's visit. Observing a child's unbridled joy during such moments is truly unmatched. Post egg-hunt, we attended church as a family. While engaging with the Easter Bunny is enjoyable, we ensure that our children comprehend the deeper significance of our holidays. This Easter was particularly special, as it was Megan's first, and she was absolutely adorable in her jean dress and stockings.

On Friday, November 22, 2002, I was thrilled because my new boots had arrived at my home. Unfortunately, I had mistakenly sent them there instead of my workplace, which meant I had to wait an extra four hours before I could wear them. I was particularly excited about these boots – they were the Face boots and Tredair flame boots – and I felt like I was on top of the world. Amidst this excitement, I ran into a bit of trouble when I discovered a flat tire on my car. Fortunately, I was already at work, so the helpful folks there offered to inflate the tire for me. If inflation didn't solve the issue, they were prepared to replace it with my full-sized spare. On the bright side, this mishap gave me an excuse to potentially shop for a new tire at Hamad Tire. While dealing with this, I was also pondering over the possibility of having come across another VW.

In a prior message, I seemed to defend and align with parents, but I've since reconsidered my stance. Parents are often clueless, assuming they understand us deeply, perhaps even believing they're capable of interpreting our emotions merely by looking at us. But, this is far from the truth. They're not aware of what truly goes on with us. For instance, just moments ago, I had a fallout with Nicole over Kelli, and upon my retreat upstairs, my parents were eager for me to discuss the problem. Their insistence is aggravating—I'm under no obligation to divulge every issue to them. As for Nicole and Kelli, there's no secret there; they simply cannot stand each other.

Today’s tunes: jamming to 94.7 FM nearly led to a tardy arrival at work. A massive collision at 14th and Constitution has traffic in a bind across Virginia. Fortune favored me as I deftly transitioned from the far left to the far right lane, taking a detour via Route 50. This travel saga likely resonates only with locals. Disregard if you're not from the area. Sitting at my desk feels like a triumph compared to being trapped in my vehicle. In other news, Sara's curiosity led her to search for me online. To my surprise, an email I'd sent to Ivan Meisel at ESPN.com was actually published! I hadn't anticipated that my average composition would catch their attention.

In an outburst of extreme and fantastical combat jargon, an immense surge of energy is depicted. Phrases like "ultimate raging blood," "decapitation pole," "flame beam," and "hellfire kamehameha" convey a scene of intense, over-the-top action, as if from a video game or anime. This is followed by an assortment of random, nonsensical terms such as "spam mega giant power," "zoom mech," and "cannon blast flash annihilator," which create an atmosphere of chaotic excitement. Amid this whirlwind of words, the repeated phrase "I ish bord" reveals a sense of boredom beneath the bombastic exterior. The writer expresses their ennui through a nonsensical vocabulary—mixing gamer slang, intentional misspellings, and lighthearted gibberish—to convey a state of mind seeking stimulation. A recent memory of playing 'iSketch' with friends provides a brief interlude from the boredom, as the game inspired laughter and enjoyment. Returning to the repetition of "I ish bord" underscores the lingering monotony, while a final nonsensical sentence punctuates the text with continued playful absurdity.

I must say, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" was absolutely fantastic! I caught it the moment school ended on Friday – yep, I was there for the premiere! (Cheers to Mike for the ticket!) Daniel Radcliffe, our Harry Potter, has matured so quickly and looks incredibly adorable! And let's not forget Malfoy – quite amusing. The film was a thrill, though I'm docking half a star for missing some critical plot points, landing it at a 4.5-star rating. Admittedly, I didn't go all out with my attire, but I did sport a Ravenclaw tie despite my preference for Gryffindors. There's a good chance I'll return for another viewing in a fortnight.

I'm giving pear slices with peanut butter another go – this time with firm pears and my personal stash of the spread, which is still chunky instead of smooth, a detail that undoubtedly alters the taste. It's also a bit disconcerting realizing this seemingly wholesome snack actually packs a hefty 614 calories per 100 grams, which is a fifth of our small jars. I'm trying to ignore the calorie count. Fresh from spending the evening at the home of a former music instructor who's also a friend, I had a delightful time. Even though I missed a favorite TV show for the visit, I recorded it. Plus, I've found out they air reruns of the ninth season every weekday morning at 9:55. Reconnecting with my friend was pleasantly nostalgic.

The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) has been requested by the U.S. State Department to send observers from its Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights to monitor the U.S. presidential election. This is a historic first for the nation. Meanwhile, a group of thirteen congressional Democrats, including four from New York, have appealed to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan for the deployment of international observers to supervise the election proceedings in Florida. Despite these petitions, it seems that the OSCE's involvement is more about learning from the U.S. electoral system rather than overseeing it, which deviates from the initial partisan and immature request for UN oversight.

My gloomy disposition has lifted. The combination of an impending period and a delay in taking my Prozac until later in the day left me extraordinarily emotional and tearful. However, my spirits were revived by my boyfriend's unexpected visit, indulging in an ice cream sundae, and his comforting touch after experiencing a vivid nightmare involving an attack with machine guns at a news agency. Furthermore, I'm enjoying a work-free morning, yet I must contact someone at KMIZ for their rate information. This evening holds the promise of reconnecting with two of my dearest friends, Amy and Kate, amidst study breaks. Looking ahead to tomorrow, there's the exciting possibility of reuniting with someone special I've not seen in quite some time for our Weight Watchers meeting.

Recently, there's been quite a bit of drama in my life. Debbie and I had a spat regarding the selection of china for a big meal. Isn't it a bit much to expect someone to set out lavish china as if serving a massive choir? Debbie, however, had an excess of tableware: from saucers to teapots, from wine goblets to various kinds of glasses, not to mention an assortment of seven forks and spoons, along with an array of plates and bowls for every course imaginable. I was dumbfounded by the extravagance! Moreover, she scolded me for nibbling on some appetizers while we waited for the turkey to finish cooking – as if I wouldn't have enough appetite left for the main meal. Really, I had to stifle my frustration. And amid all this, I found myself rushing to the hospital to be with my dad.

The naturalization ceremony in Jacksonville, which celebrated nearly 200 new American citizens, encountered controversy after GOP volunteers were reported to have pre-registered new citizens as Republicans. The incident, highlighted by witness Linda Cross during her husband Dario Cruz's citizenship oath, led to criticism and subsequent relocation of voter registration efforts at such events. GOP activists were scrutinized for their presence and actions at the voter registration table, where they distributed forms with pre-selected party affiliations. The original instruction to visit the voter registration table by an immigration official was standard, but the involvement of partisan volunteers raised concerns. This report was brought to light by journalists Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy.

Kavitha

I've decided to take a personal day today, Wednesday, the 10th, although the post's time stamp reflects the U.S. date—so it's a tad misleading. It's a chance for me to unwind and invigorate my creativity with a full two-day stretch dedicated to daydreaming. As a foreigner, I feel quite fortunate, especially given the serendipity of my situation. Adding to my sense of good fortune is the illustration work that seemed to fall into my lap quite unexpectedly—I'd surely be grumbling if it hadn't. Despite this, I'm aware that I'm not getting the best deal financially, but I'm not turning a blind eye to it. Right now, the pangs of hunger are setting in, leading me to consider grabbing some Mexican cuisine from Speak Easy, that 'American style' diner conveniently located across from the post office in my quaint prefecture.

I take great pride in ensuring that visitors to Casa Pescatore experience the utmost comfort, just as they would in their own future homes. Yesterday, I believe I achieved that goal. A large crowd gathered on Perry Avenue, some saying with considerable fervor. At 4:30 p.m., my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived, bearing a large pan of baked ziti. I had everything prepared, the tables set, food I personally prepared, as the bells went wild in announcement. Then, to my delight, my best friend from Florida entered, bringing an instant smile to my face. I had missed him tremendously. His arrival was even more meaningful, as he brought his pregnant wife, allowing me to embrace the role of an honorary uncle. I doted on her, serving dish after dish, including her with trays of food and the delightful tiramisu.

The concept intrigued me, suggesting it might have offered an escape from accusations of witchcraft. Though I'm a non-American blogger and was initially hesitant to wade into debates about flag-related issues, I feel compelled to comment since I broached the topic. To be clear, I find the notion of legislation prohibiting flag desecration to be ludicrous. By elevating a symbolic entity—any symbol—to a status that requires mandatory respect and legal safeguarding, we edge closer to authoritarianism. The nature of symbols is inherently unstable; they hold no intrinsic meaning but rather gain significance through collective interpretation and assigned representation.

The prom is just a day away, and I'm truly hoping it will be an enjoyable experience—that's my sole wish. In three weeks, on May 14th, Rob's arrival is slated, and the anticipation is nearly overwhelming, as it's causing me quite a bit of stress; nevertheless, the excitement, coupled with a slight bit of fear, is undeniable. Last evening, the Leafs had a game; however, since I'm located on the West Coast and the Calgary team also had a match, I ended up watching that one instead. Although my loyalty lies with the Leafs, who, to my disappointment, lost their game, I take some solace in knowing that they've outperformed the Canucks, preserving my pride. And today just seems to be one hectic day.

As of now, I haven't seen the final appearance of my blog, though this seems to be the right place to begin. I'm uncertain about how things are going to unfold here—whether blogging will be my thing. However, considering the substantial time I spend at a computer, it seems wise to utilize that time by sharing the multitude of thoughts, albeit disorganized, that roam my mind. Inspiration struck from a blogger I've never met face-to-face. She had a knack for intimately sharing daily life updates in a way that both informed and amused us.

So, what's the film obsession that rules your world? Mine's clear as daylight: the Evil Dead series. I'm pretty proud of my extensive memorabilia collection from those films. And when it comes to making music, I'm all about the bass guitar; I love to play some serious tunes. As for the habits that hit my wallet the hardest? It's a fierce competition between scooping up DVDs and grabbing the latest tech gadgets. Now about quirks or fears? Honestly, I'm free from phobias and allergies, but there's one thing I've got to do: line up all the cash in my wallet, smallest to largest, without fail. Lastly, on that age-old riddle about a woodchuck's wood-chucking capabilities? The answer's straightforward just because I decide it is.

I have documented the details and pricing for two transactions within the Sitara platform: Transaction 418015, which involves CNG at the Citygate with Tennessee production and transportation included, and transaction 418065, which relates to CGas at the Citygate with TRCO and CGLF production costs, as well as transport fees for TRCO, CGLF, and CGas (note that this task is time-consuming). There is a question of whether we should deactivate the automatic confirmation feature as it seems each time a VNG deal is initialized, a confirmation fax is automatically sent. Suggestions for more efficient deal processing are welcome — if presenting these as production area sales is more suitable, I am open to feedback. The simplest method I have identified thus far is to register the sales at the Citygate or a storage location and handle most of the pricing calculations externally in a spreadsheet.

The game consistently delivers an outstanding experience, earning an unequivocal endorsement due to its top-notch performance and features. It has impressively surpassed all anticipations, likely yours included, with its seamless gameplay devoid of any glitches or crashes. It offers a rich narrative and a plethora of content that ensures varied engagement through multiple daily activities, ranging from numerous practice sessions and sponsorship events to actual matches. My appraisal is exclusively from the perspective of the MyCareer mode, which I rate as flawless. Even the face scan function proved to be successful, despite an initial hiccup. It's worth noting that the companion app, myNBA2K17, not only facilitates complimentary face scans but also provides opportunities to accumulate daily virtual currency.

Caution to all who love magic - Wizards seems to overlook the true nature of Magic: The Gathering as a profoundly social experience. At its heart, this is a game to revel in with peers, enjoying the competitive banter and savoring those thrilling moments of victory. Yet, it appears Wizards of the Coast has strayed from this path. The enjoyment of playing with friends is hindered by a system where essential in-game currency - gold - cannot be earned. Gold's significance is underscored by a daily limit, a logical move given it's the key to unlocking in-game content. However, players are forced into a tedious solo quest against AI or silent strangers, absent any camaraderie. Those determined to advance without spending cash face a solitary and daunting endeavor, possibly stretching over a month, just to acquire their deck's components.

As the third part of the series, let's address the negatives upfront. Prequels often frustrate me because they reverse the narrative rather than advancing it, a common issue with such storylines. While they do expand the narrative, this one falls short. The combat system is a letdown; it lacks the precision that Arkham City achieved. At the time of this review (October 26, 2013), there's a critical bug in the game that renders one of the side missions incomplete, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Additionally, some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring an awkward stretch across the keyboard, which can disrupt the fluidity of combat and could ruin your combo.

The revised essence of the original text, with word count maintained within the +/- 10% range:  Essentially, the improvements made to Shadow Warrior (2013) are notable. Specifically, the boss fights are impressive, and the weapons are satisfying to use, though they may not reach the benchmark set by DOOM's arsenal. The enemies strike a good balance in terms of resilience, assuming the player adeptly manages elemental forces and upgrades. The upgrade mechanics are well-tuned, avoiding unnecessary complexity. Ammo scarcity and various elemental effects encourage the strategic use of an array of distinct weapons, deviating significantly from the generic, randomized weapons found in games like Borderlands. Additionally, the soundtrack is a standout feature, with the main theme and Stan Bush's contributions being particularly memorable.

Numerous issues have detracted from the overall experience I've had with my career in the game. Starting a review feels daunting given the magnitude of the flaws at hand. Specifically addressing the elements tied to my in-game character, an outside scorer playing point guard, standing at 1.71 meters with fully-enhanced attributes and all the essential perks acquired. It baffles me as to why shooting capabilities are determined by a player's height. It seems illogical that a character who is slightly taller at 1.74 meters wouldn't be able to achieve the same level of shooting proficiency as one who is 1.71 meters. Personally, I'm 1.87 meters tall in real life, and I modeled my first player after my own height. To my disappointment, I discovered that my player was capped at a shooting skill of 89, with no possibility of improvement. This limitation feels discriminatory and arbitrary. What is more frustrating is that the game fails to convey this information upfront. I was not informed of this restriction upon creating my character, nor was I warned when I hit this unanticipated ceiling after weeks of dedicated play. This lack of transparency is disheartening and detracts from the gaming experience.

In my view, the latest Assassin's Creed has superbly executed various gameplay elements such as naval combat, maritime exploration, fishing, and free-running. The protagonist garnered a deeper connection from me, enhancing the gaming experience. Initially, the narrative is quite tough but significantly improves as the game progresses—an aspect I find common to the series. Edward's character was intriguing, alongside compelling supporting characters. This installment differentiated itself by giving collectibles a greater sense of value and relevance, unlike its predecessors—a detail I found particularly satisfying. Although these items weren't essential to game progression, seeking them out provided a satisfying balance of challenge and reward.

While I don't wholly endorse this game, it's not the worst I've played. The gameplay involving firearms is decent, assuming you're willing to spend on weapon upgrades, which leads to my primary issue with this title: its reliance on a pay-to-win model. Putting that aspect aside, there are enjoyable elements like using the hardsuit and the innovative hrv feature. This game, despite its flaws, would be my pick over any Call of Duty release. However, the pay-to-win aspect is a significant turnoff for me. If that business model doesn't bother you, then you might enjoy this game. But for those who share my aversion to pay-to-win strategies, it's best to skip this one as it likely won't suit your tastes.

Despite not being flawless, the game has proven to be immensely fun. Issues with the saving mechanism and the risk of abrupt character demise can be annoying. During my initial journey through the game, I suffered a significant setback when I lost my primary character halfway, wishing for a chance to reload a save. To circumvent such devastating losses in the future, I've integrated an unofficial modification for saving. Additionally, the target marker is a tad too diminutive, and the zoom function could be more effective. Nevertheless, the experience has been exciting. Typically, zombie themes don't entice me, but this game's fusion of tactical elements, various missions, and first-person combat has captured my attention. I find myself squeezing in gaming sessions whenever possible. It's always 'just one more mission, just one more foraging trip', or ensuring my safety before exiting the game.

This strategy game is outstanding! Having experienced every single wargame out there, like European Escalation and ALB, I can confidently say that this title stands out impressively. There's an astonishing array of units available – the exact number eludes me, but it's vast! The graphics are stunningly beautiful, the sound effects are top-notch, and the overall gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box on the main menu provides its own form of entertainment – and I'm totally serious about that. But be warned: if you're new to the strategy scene or think this game will be a walk in the park, be prepared for a challenge. It might take considerable time to master. Expect to lose a lot of units and face frustration. The key to success involves meticulous planning, as well as ensuring you're equipped with anti-air and anti-tank capabilities.

Before experiencing the game first-hand, I held a rather skeptical stance towards it and was hesitant to even make the purchase. The whole concept of a portal gun and the use of portals struck me as strange, in spite of my affinity for science fiction. However, once I gave it a shot, I realized how incorrect my preconceptions were. The humor interlaced with the stellar voice acting is nothing short of spectacular – it's both clever and entertaining, occasionally bordering on cheesy in the best way possible. Each character in the story is infused with a unique brand of wit, bringing a dynamic range of personalities to life. On top of that, the level design is outstandingly cool. I hadn't dabbled with the original Portal, but after being captivated by the sequel, I'm definitely considering setting aside some time to explore where it all began.

Starting with the benefits and drawbacks, as well as my personal take on this game. The game shines with outstanding characters and an engaging storyline. It's rich in content, offering a customizable protagonist, with options for both gender and relationships with many companions, catering to those who enjoy a romantic angle. On the downside, the graphics are lacking, love scenes come off as awkward, there's the occasional invisible wall, and one particular mission felt dull—though tastes in games can vary. Something neutral to note: the protagonist that players design doesn't have a voice. Now, for my perspective: I'm genuinely smitten with this game. It ranks incredibly high in my list of all-time favorite RPGs, possibly even games as a whole. Any RPG aficionado likely already owns this gem.

Indeed, for those in their thirties who nostalgically recall tolerating Timmy Mallet on UK television as a precursor to a brief Transformers segment, this experience will resonate deeply. The voices of iconic characters like Optimus Prime, Megatron, and Bumblebee return with a familiar ring, alongside the classic transforming sound effects from the original cartoon. The game dazzles with a cell-shaded aesthetic that pays homage to the first-generation Transformers. Yet, it's more than a trip down memory lane; the game impresses with its dynamic combat system. Seamlessly integrating transformations into fluid combos is not only thrilling but often essential for battle strategy, setting it apart from the acclaimed Cybertron series by High Moon Studios. While melee attacks take center stage, the game design cleverly necessitates the occasional switch to ranged weapons when facing certain adversaries like the Seekers.

After downloading and briefly playing the game, I found it unexceptional. The majority of my time was consumed by login issues due to a persistent glitch where I kept encountering a notification about an updated terms of service; accepting it only led to repetition until I restarted the client. Additionally, linking my Steam and GFACE accounts, purportedly for DLC purposes, felt unnecessary and permanent—now a company I'm indifferent about has my Steam details. As for the gameplay, it was mediocre, clearly imitating Call of Duty, yet with inferior shooting mechanics, a surprising downgrade from the original formula.

Experience stunning 4K resolution at 60fps on a GTX 970, choose from dual audio options, and enjoy the addition of Neptune gear in this acclaimed port. It's easy to see why it's beloved. Check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. This game serves as an ideal introduction for newcomers to the franchise, but be prepared for extensive, yet skippable, dialogue. Gamers often prefer a gamepad, but the keymouse/mouse configuration works smoothly and can be customized to your preferences. The pricing feels fair, and with the bonus of most DLC included at no extra cost, there's a wealth of content at your fingertips. I heartily recommend it to fans of JRPGs, anime, or visual novels – just be prepared for some downtime between engaging sequences. Enjoy the pure gaming experience with a no commentary playlist here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSlFVIJaUPsZeZ9Af395mvNk63XnHSJ1_.

From the outset, I encountered zero issues with how the game performed, and it's only improved with subsequent updates. In my view, it stands out as an exceptional and highly entertaining game, despite a certain annoyance with the free-roam city mechanics that reintroduce adversaries with each narrative advancement. The highlight for me was the innovative 'dual play' feature, allowing control of Batman alongside an ally, enhancing the gameplay experience. I also appreciated the versatility of control options, with the standard controller suffice for general gameplay, while the precision of mouse and keyboard was ideal for the tank combat scenarios. Navigating Gotham in the batmobile adds to the thrill, especially when pursuing apc commanders. Mastering the art of skidding through the city's corners by deftly applying the brakes elevates the driving experience, making it thoroughly gratifying.

In essence, the game in question delivers an outstanding first-person shooter experience. The overall quality is highlighted through its stellar graphics and audio, engaging gameplay mechanics, compelling narrative, intriguing characters, spot-on voice acting, and a powerful soundtrack. However, it's not for the sensitive, with some graphic and intense cutscenes. Despite the game's excellence, a few blemishes stand out. Notably, there's no support for SLI configurations; players without strong single GPU systems, like those using older dual GPU setups, may need an upgrade to enjoy smooth gameplay. Additionally, the game features frustratingly impassable minor obstacles.

As English isn't my first language—I'm Dutch—I hope you'll overlook any typos or grammatical errors in my review of an exceptional game. I'll evaluate the game across several aspects: - **Graphics**: Characterized by a comic book aesthetic, the visuals are both sophisticated and uncluttered, boasting appealing color schemes that enhance the game's style. Impressively, even on high settings, the graphics don’t overburden your system. I play on an i5 Pentium with an Nvidia GeForce 710M, 8GB of RAM, and it delivers smooth performance on Windows 8.1.
  
- **Controls**: Flexibility is key here; the game supports both keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller for gameplay, offering accessibility for players' preferred input methods.

The fervent dedication I've shown to this game is a testament to my enjoyment. It perfectly embodies what I envisioned for a search game within the COD franchise. However, this title should not be mistaken for typical shooters like COD, Battlefield, or their kin – it's in a league of its own and demands to be recognized as such. The frustration from novices who bemoan their swift defeats is all too common – they seem surprised when a bullet to the head results in their in-game demise, mirroring a very real consequence. Since I've been immersed in the game and invested significant money into it, I can confidently say it stands as one of the top multiplayer games out there, an excellent alternative for times when the appeal of CS:GO dims.

Having spent a couple of hours immersed in this video game, I find myself thoroughly entertained by its humor—it’s downright hilarious. The mechanics of the game are robust, complemented by stunning visuals and an unexpectedly top-notch, fitting soundtrack. Its narrative and setting are captivating, and it also offers delightful puzzles. Yet, it's the humor that truly sets this title apart. Fans of role-playing games will appreciate the various winks and nods to the genre, including clever parodies and references that veteran gamers will recognize. Those new to RPGs will still find plenty of joy in its comedic aspects. Particularly, those familiar with classics like Final Fantasy 7 or 10 will find this game to be a must-play. Indeed, its humor had me literally pausing the game to give my aching cheeks a rest from non-stop laughter—truly entertaining, to say the least.

I apologize, as I generally endeavor to support both free-to-play titles and independent game creators; however, this title failed to captivate me. Despite the game's concept seeming like my ideal genre, its realization has fallen short of my expectations. My enthusiasm for puzzles and exploratory games could not salvage my experience, as I found the gameplay unintuitive and not enjoyable even with guidance. A glaring omission is the apparent lack of a pause function, which, considering the game's time-sensitive events, is a significant flaw. Additionally, the game feels heavily skewed towards cut scenes rather than interactive gameplay, leaving me frequently idle and restless.

Wow, where to begin with this gem of a game? It captivated me with its breathtaking narrative and stunning visuals. The story wasn't just engaging; it was immersive, drawing me in as if I were the protagonist navigating the unfolding tale. The gameplay was top-notch, and it surprisingly became a journey of self-discovery, revealing my newfound fear of heights in the midst of the chilling ice caverns. Despite a churning gut feeling, my determination to succeed for uncle fred kept me going. Should a DLC or sequel be released, I'd not only be the first in line to purchase it but also highly recommend it to my circle. Kudos to the entire team for crafting such a masterwork.

"Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth" reimagines the classic turn-based strategy game by propelling players into the future where the objective is to establish and grow a civilization on an extraterrestrial planet, diverging from the historical Earth setting of past installments that spanned the Stone Age to the Modern Age. What stands out in this iteration is 2K's innovative take, particularly with the introduction of novel game mechanics like the affinity system and the orbital layer. Despite these exciting additions, the complexity they introduce can sometimes be daunting. One area ripe for enhancement is the game's visual artistry—integrating more detailed environmental graphics, especially during interactions with other leaders, could greatly enrich the overall experience.

This fantastic game ranks among my top five favorite zombie survival experiences due to its high replay value and engaging gameplay. I've invested over 60 hours, confirming it stands out for its authentic approach to the genre. It cleverly incorporates classic survival horror elements, such as the need to conserve ammunition, treat wounds, and use medication to stave off infection. The animation of zombies is impressively lifelike, particularly for a free-to-play title. Additionally, partnering with one or two friends enhances the experience, but even solo players can enjoy interacting with the game's welcoming community, either through text chat or voice communication.

It's regrettable that despite the game's addictive potential, I can't fully endorse or enjoy it due to two major issues that disrupt the gameplay experience. Firstly, the absence of Australian servers causes significant lag, indicated by a red bar, which places players at a considerable disadvantage. This lag is puzzlingly present even in offline training mode, an issue that perplexes me. Additionally, the game suffers from excessive artifacting across menus, backgrounds, training, and actual gameplay. Having never encountered such a problem with my graphics card, I suspected the issue might stem from overclocking. However, reverting the GPU to its default settings failed to resolve the artifacting, solidifying its standing as a persistent detriment to the game's playability.

Late last night, I completed the game. Although the plot itself isn't particularly profound or captivating, the manner in which it's conveyed really makes an impact due to the incredibly immersive environment and the extensive range of collectibles that richly enhance the experience. It was enlightening to explore the universe of Batman, though I found it slightly disheartening that the game featured just a handful of boss characters. Nonetheless, with more games on the horizon, this might well be addressed in future installments. The combat strikes a balance, tending towards the easier side, offering a moderate level of challenge. The process of powering up Batman fell a bit flat for me, however. The real joy came from the gadgets, both those improved and newly acquired throughout the game, as they introduced fresh gameplay elements. Moreover, the ability to reach new areas previously inaccessible in the game granted a rewarding feeling of advancement.

"To the Moon" transcends a standard gaming experience; it stands as an unparalleled journey that has marked one of the finest episodes of my existence. Should you consider the poignancy of Telltale's "The Walking Dead" to be a high benchmark of emotion, prepare to be astounded, for "To the Moon" eclipses it with ease. I have never encountered such a potent blend of heartache and gratification from a work of fiction. In my eyes, this gem occupies the zenith of narrative craft, accompanied by a soundtrack that's as exquisitely delightful as it is impeccably suited to the mood. Granted, the gameplay mechanics could be smoother, and the game's controls might challenge your patience, yet the brilliance of its narrative makes such trifles inconsequential. The wit within the game shines, complementing rather than overshadowing the gravitas of the plot, while a bounty of "Doctor Who" allusions await the keen-eyed aficionado.

"Bastion" is an outstanding video game that captivates players with its compelling narrative. The game begins amid the aftermath of a disaster, where your mission is to restore the bastion. Players are offered extensive choices throughout the game, such as selecting structures that provide benefits, choosing from an arsenal for combat, applying enhancements to these weapons, and deciding on beverages that grant additional perks. The game's aesthetic is striking, with a vibrant art style and a soundtrack that's equally impressive, proving that a post-apocalyptic world can be anything but monotonous. What truly sets "Bastion" apart is its dynamic narration that reacts to the player's actions. For instance, if a player swaps weapons in the armoury, the narrator will comment on the newfound armament, adding a personalized touch to the gaming experience.

I initially purchased the game during its early development stage, when the sole in-game currency was spacebux, and it lacked a 'tech tree'. At this golden stage, the game was truly enjoyable. The firearms were all immensely powerful to the point of absurdity, allowing for an even playing field because anybody could defeat anyone else at any given time. Additionally, the game generously offered players unlimited gun slots and five different loadout options. For a game boasting a veritable arsenal of 'bajillions of guns', it's rather stingy that players are now restricted to a meager six weapon slots and merely three loadouts unless they're willing to spend real money. I remember having gathered roughly three pages of guns and was brainstorming for even more innovative designs, as that's what brought joy to my gaming experience.

This title turned out to be an unexpected delight. Often, the high praise for certain items can be deceptive, but the positive critiques for this charming game are spot-on. It cleverly blends the traditional 2D platforming with elements of a MOBA, creating an engaging experience with a dash of panache. To my own surprise, I became fond of certain characters that typically wouldn't capture my attention in similar MOBA titles. Initially skeptical, I ventured to play as a melee tank, which resulted in a gratifying revelation, prompting me to experiment with other characters as I unlocked them through gameplay. The game's art and user interface add to its endearing qualities. It's become so influential to me that I've adopted a character as my avatar and even chose a game-themed wallpaper after completing a card set.

I've recently begun playing this game and I'm totally enamored with it. When I slip into my headphones, I find myself immersed for extensive periods. It's rare for a game to captivate me like this. The soundtrack creates the perfect atmosphere, the audio effects hit the mark, and the gameplay mechanics are spot-on. I eagerly anticipate each battle, which has been highly refined. Initially skeptical about the naval combat, I've discovered it's incredibly satisfying to decimate enemy fleets. The only path to defeat is not knowing when to withdraw. If a battle seems daunting, the key is to retreat, regroup, and come back for a tactical counterattack. Kudos to the developers for crafting such a thrilling gaming journey!

The recent overhaul of the "Devil May Cry" series has introduced significant alterations, especially to its central character, Dante. Devotees of the classic series might find themselves disconcerted by these transformations, but they are undeniably improvements, as demonstrated by Ninja Theory’s latest installment. This fresh iteration is the ideal entry point for newcomers, presenting Dante's evolution from a brash and sceptical youth to a hero marked by selflessness. The game artfully crafts a vivid journey of personal growth for Dante as he awakens to the corruption around him that he had once blissfully overlooked.

Embarking on the journey through this exquisitely crafted game is a delight. The narrative is enchantingly engaging, intricately detailed, and radiates sheer joy, humor, and playful mischief, complete with whimsical dogs and hidden elements. Its storytelling adeptly toggles between solemn and lighthearted, ensuring the timing is always right. Character development is strikingly effective, with a diverse cast each presenting unique traits and mysteries. This game distinguishes itself within the RPG genre by offering a path of non-violence, a rarity in such games. The influence of Earthbound is evident, indicating its high-quality pedigree. Moreover, the soundtrack is unparalleled, the finest I've encountered in a remarkable while.

I'm suggesting this primarily because it's available at no cost and could potentially offer a more pleasant time for some people. However, personally, the 'game' left me unaffected. It heavily leans on elements of shock to drive the narrative, but none of it stirred any shock or emotional response from me. It's possible that I've grown too accustomed to such stimuli, or perhaps the content was too rudimentary to elicit any sort of reaction. On the other hand, the game attempts to depict someone's mental deterioration through various themes like obsession, hallucination, and depression, among others. The concept seems intriguing on paper. Yet, it took merely 10 minutes to finish the game, even with a thorough engagement and absorption of all the details presented.

Is it really necessary to elaborate on the brilliance of Portal? This ingenious puzzle game introduces a concept and then stands back, allowing players to engage in a mentally stimulating experience that remains enjoyable throughout. While the narrative may not be its strongest attribute, Portal was instrumental in setting the stage for one of the standout hits of 2011—continuing to captivate players like myself who return regularly to tackle its challenges and appreciate the roots of what has become an iconic game. As for the mechanics of Portal, they’re deceptively straightforward. The game revolves around the strategic use of portals to navigate obstacles and solve puzzles. Within these puzzles, players find two types of buttons: one is a standard button which can be pressed by the player, and the other requires the placement of a weighted cube to be activated. This simplicity in design belies the depth and enjoyment found in the game's compelling puzzle-solving gameplay.

Despite encountering only two glitches during my gameplay—one of which was somewhat bothersome, yet both issues have since been resolved with fixes that notably improved my frame rate from 60-90 to 80-120—I would without hesitation recommend this space exploration game. There's a lot of discussion regarding system specifications in reviews, so here are mine: an i5 6600k (priced around 200€), a Radeon RX480 (also approximately 200€), a Z170 Pro-Gaming motherboard (about 150€), and 16GB of DDR4 RAM (costing roughly 70€). In total, my setup cost around 650€, which is fairly mid-range in terms of price, and it's worth noting it is pretty up-to-date. I'm consistently getting over 60 fps with high graphical settings and Vsync on. It's surprising to read that 90% of users are reporting a mere 20fps even with high-end equipment, which strikes me as an anomaly based on my own positive experience.

Do you recall the classic "Age of Mythology"? It's been quite some time since a real-time strategy (RTS) game of that caliber has graced the scene. "Divinity: Dragon Commander" nearly achieves that level for me, situating itself among my all-time favorite RTS games. When you meld that with an expansive, Risk-like strategy layer, it really hits home. I strive (or rather, I try to remain impartial) not to let my enthusiasm for the game's feature that enables you to morph into a dragon – offering support to your troops, leading assaults, and controlling unit production and deployment simultaneously – cloud my judgment. I must confess, I have a penchant for today's intricate RTS games, much like "Civ V". These games often pack a mix of complex mechanics, detailed charts, and an abundance of resources into a single, convoluted gameplay experience.

"Undertale" is more than just the elements it's composed of. With its retro-styled visuals and delightful soundtrack, the game expertly crafts moments that truly resonate. The writing is masterful, effortlessly shifting from humor to drama, from sorrow to hope, while cleverly subverting typical role-playing game conventions. Yet, this only brushes the surface of "Undertale's" rich world, intricate characters, compelling narrative, and engaging gameplay. It's a title I could expound on at length, but to keep it brief: whether you're a fan of RPGs or video games in general, or simply someone with a spare seven hours, "Undale" is a must-play experience.

Fans of the first two Witcher games should definitely consider picking up The Witcher 3. Under normal circumstances, I would rate this game a perfect 10/10. However, since the 1.03 update, the game has been plagued with numerous glitches and unexpected crashes, which makes frequent saving an absolute necessity. Prior to this update, from versions 1.00 to 1.03, I experienced a smooth run without crashes or bugs. Post-update, there are noticeable issues with the rendering distance as well, with objects and characters popping into view only when approaching them closely. Despite these technical issues, The Witcher 3 is an outstanding title, especially due to the effort put into crafting its quests—many of which are emotionally resonant and deeply engaging. The plethora of side quests and the impactful nature of player choices add to the game's richness. Having invested over 50 hours into it, I'm still enthralled and continuing my adventure.

Having possessed this game for only a few months, I've observed its transformation from great to excellent with the release of two DLCs and significant patches. The developers interact extensively with the player base, evident in numerous discussion platforms and development updates. Mastering the game's intricate mechanics presents a challenge I'm currently embracing. Yet, such depth affords countless strategic avenues for achieving objectives and leveraging scenarios. To me, the game's potential for replayability seems boundless, as each session captivates me without fail, regardless of the play-through’s progression.

Initially, Warframe presents as an exciting venture, offering several hours of engaging gameplay. However, as time progresses, a pattern of redundancy may emerge, manifesting through similar combat styles, adversaries, and overall mechanics. Despite this, a notable aspect of the game is the dedication of its developers, who routinely roll out comprehensive updates—ranging from major overhauls of existing systems to the introduction of new characters and various enhancements. For those who enjoy a leisurely gaming experience, Warframe can be a fitting choice, albeit there's a possibility that the game might not sustain your interest in the long term, particularly if repetitious tasks are not your preference. Nevertheless, given that the game can be enjoyed at no cost, it is certainly worth giving it a try, especially for players seeking a brief and enjoyable distraction.

This video game fails to deliver any sort of enjoyment; it's simply dull. I was under the impression that it would be a computer adaptation of "Katamari Damacy," which was a delightful and well-received title on the PlayStation 2. However, that's not the case. The objective is to essentially navigate around, assimilating objects of increasing size to gradually escalate your own dimensions. Regrettably, the experience is hindered by clunky gameplay and uninspired level design. What's more, the game's ambiance is not the charming kind of bizarre; it's disconcertingly morose, to the point of prompting existential contemplation. The manner in which 'alive' entities are portrayed, from tiny domestic animals to humans, gives one the unnerving suspicion that the developers might have a penchant for taxidermy.

Understandably curious about politics, I was naturally drawn to a game that promised a simulation of the journey towards the presidency. Initially thrilled at the concept, my excitement quickly diminished upon playing. The game restricts you to choose between the Republican or Democratic parties, offering no room for independent or third-party candidates. Despite this setback, I remained hopeful and continued to explore the game. One commendable feature is the character customization. While not extensive, it provides a playful element, amusingly allowing players to choose whether to don headgear during their virtual campaign—an unusual choice that's not available beyond this point.

The story in Fallout 3 outshines that of this game. Its complex narrative is overshadowed by the overbearing nature of managing settlements, which becomes so tedious it detracts from the gaming experience. Additionally, players face the inconvenience of certain keys that are immovable due to hard coding. The game is riddled with bugs; a noteworthy one includes the disappearance of the Pip-Boy, requiring players to delve into console commands to retrieve it. The iconic power armor, a hallmark of past Fallout games, is disappointingly easy to acquire early on, with an abundance of power cores readily available at trader locations, lessening its significance. The story and overall game quality are average, at best, a stark contrast to its predecessors. Unlike Fallout 3, which was plagued with crashes, this game boasts remarkable stability—the one aspect where it does excel. Despite these points, this game fails to surpass both Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Coupled with the excessive anticipation that preceded its release, the game falls short of expectations and cannot be considered an improvement over its renowned forerunners.

At the time I crafted this critique, I had invested 8.6 hours reaching the game's conclusion, unearthed 10 out of 25 collectibles, and secured none of the 15 achievements. What was appealing included the graphics for most of the journey, up until the icy caverns of the final stage. While the narrative was lackluster, a twist post-credits somewhat compensated for the time I dedicated to playing. On the downside, the visual appeal dropped off significantly during the ultimate level, and the gameplay's marked increase in difficulty resulted in a tedious cycle of repetition and irritation. Additionally, the achievements prove excessively challenging, with a mere 2.1% of players managing to snag 13 of the 15 available.

Advantages of the game include its impressive graphics. However, the experience is marred by numerous issues. Players frequently encounter glitches, particularly with the game's environment, which can cause characters to get stuck or shots to be blocked by invisible barriers despite a clear view of the target. The game overly guides the player, diminishing the challenge and sense of achievement. The artificial intelligence of the opponents is disappointing, with enemies possessing an unrealistic awareness of the player's location once detected. Additionally, foes display an unreasonably high level of shooting accuracy, reminiscent of the frustrating experience in the first Ghost Warrior title. Save points and checkpoints are poorly implemented, further aggravating the player experience. The narrative fails to engage, leaving much to be desired. Overall, the game is not recommended unless heavily discounted, and even then, it's considered a tedious task rather than an enjoyable pastime. The player expresses regret over the time spent on the first Ghost Warrior game and anticipates a similar lack of motivation to complete this installment.

Do not purchase this video game; the servers are consistently offline, rendering it unplayable. Initially, the gameplay was enjoyable. However, it evokes a reminiscent feeling similar to a Steve Miller Band track, metaphorically suggesting that the company has taken the money and absconded. Experience with the game, despite being limited to a mere 73 minutes, was fantastic. Certain weapons in the game disproportionately overpower others, and occasionally the matchmaking system seems unjust—more so than in Battlefield 3—pairing inexperienced players with advanced ones. Moreover, there appears to be an issue with the game's realism, as shooting opponents in the face yields no result.

Wouldn't it be delightful to don a fez? In this charming puzzle-platformer, you play as a diminutive character adorned with a fez, who embarks on an adventure to gather tiny fragments and assemble them into a full cube while exploring an expansive, intricately connected map. The experience is thoroughly entertaining, and progressing through the game to reach its conclusion offers plenty of enjoyment. Nevertheless, the pursuit of every cube and achievement might present a mild annoyance. Completing the collection demands deciphering challenging codes, which range in complexity from mere moments to potentially leading to exasperation and the surrender to a walkthrough (I admit, I succumbed and consulted a guide). This guide, titled "A Complete Guide to Fez!!!," could be your salvation.

I understand the appeal of the game to others, yet it failed to captivate me. Equipped with a Vive, my preference leans towards expansive room-scale experiences utilizing the interactive controllers. Although the vastness of the game's universe initially captivated me, it eventually became overwhelming and somewhat diminished my pleasure. The steep learning curve coupled with the significant time investment required to reach engaging gameplay elements proved excessive. With limited patience and time to dedicate to gaming, this particular game didn't resonate with me, especially when there is a plethora of other VR titles I'd prefer to explore.

Without question, the first-person shooter that tops my list is one that calls for strategic precision rather than mindless sprinting and shooting. For enthusiasts seeking a true-to-life combat experience, this is the perfect match. The game employs authentic recoil and bullet behavior, with accurate shots to vital areas like the chest, neck, or head from rifles being lethal in almost all instances, save for the occasional superficial wound. Bullets are subject to gravity, making long-range combat a matter of skillful, brief bursts to ensure accuracy. The game abandons the concept of infinite ammo supplies — if you consistently reload before emptying your magazine, you'll end up with a collection of partially spent clips. Stamina is finite; too much running impairs your shooting precision as your character struggles to regain composure and breath. To increase accuracy, the game recommends using the environment — resting your weapon on your elbows when prone or against a support like a window ledge. Shooting accuracy decreases significantly when you take shots while standing.

I want to clarify that I didn't buy the original EU game upon release but rather snagged a deal later on that included the expansion EW, so I can't relate to the early problems others might've had. However, I absolutely enjoyed the game despite its initial difficulty, as it felt gratifying to succeed through its challenges. Regarding XCOM2, it's a fantastic experience for me; on a medium setting, it runs smoothly on my GTX560, equipped with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to a high setting which slightly hindered performance, but after adjusting it to medium, everything became much smoother. It's possible I'm just fortunate when it comes to avoiding issues commonly cited in gaming, but in my view, many of the negative critiques appear to be expressed by individuals with rather entitled perspectives.

This game delivers an enjoyable experience, featuring a diverse selection of ship types and a physics-based system that governs the movement of both ships and missiles. Players will appreciate the straightforward resource management system, all presented with a layer of dark humor. However, the game could benefit from a wider array of equipment options and a more elaborate skill leveling system with more branches. It can become a bit tedious to grind, particularly if you're not fully utilizing the civilian stations available. Also, the AI teammates leave something to be desired. Nonetheless, the game captivates with its fast-paced start and continues to escalate in excitement. Despite some limitations in equipment and skills, the thrill of unlocking new ships and leveling up is persistent. Moreover, mods significantly enhance the gameplay; especially notable are "Fight for Universe" and "Big Fight for Beef," with the former being a standout. These modifications are key to prolonging the game's enjoyment and depth.

Over 2,000 influential figures from across the globe are convening at the Swiss alpine resort of Davos for the prestigious World Economic Forum (WEF). Throughout the five-day event, dignitaries will tackle a variety of pressing topics, including China's economic influence and the outlook for Iraq post-election. Notable attendees include UK's Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among others comprising 20 national leaders. This year contrasts prior ones as expected demonstrations against the WEF by adversaries of globalization have been subdued, with activists cancelling a planned weekend protest. Simultaneously, the Brazilian municipality of Porto Alegre is set to host an alternative conference, the World Social Forum, which serves as an ideological counterpoint to Davos's glitzy gathering.

Time is running out for Fiat and General Motors (GM), as they face a 1 February midnight deadline to resolve their dispute regarding a potential acquisition. This date signifies when Fiat is entitled to sell its automotive section to GM, which was initially agreed upon in a 2000 alliance. However, GM, struggling with its own European ventures, is reluctant to acquire Fiat's loss-making car division. Fiat's stagnant negotiation reports have led to a slight decline in its stock value by 1.2% this Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday fuelled by the anticipation of a resolution. GM reportedly proposes to pay around $2 billion to withdraw from the deal, claiming it was invalidated after Fiat divested its finance division and diminished GM's share through a fund-raising strategy. This contested agreement stems from the earlier competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form a partnership with Fiat.
